title: The 2024 Atlantic hurricane season will be  extraordinary , forecasters warn
message:
This year’s Atlantic hurricane season is expected to be extremely active, putting tens of millions of Americans in the eastern half of the country at risk from flooding and damaging winds, forecasters at the National Hurricane Center warn.
Forecasters expect 17 to 25 storms to form in the Atlantic between June 1 and the end of November.
It’s the largest number of storms ever forecast for the Atlantic, and is well above the average of 14 storms that usually occur in a given hurricane season.
“This season is looking to be an extraordinary one,” says Rick Spinrad, the administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which houses the National Hurricane Center.
Warm water is fuel for storms, because heat provides energy for the storm’s winds and warmer water provides more moisture, leading to large, powerful and rainy storms.

title: INT : NOAA issue most dire hurricane season prediction in their history
message:
NOAA issue most dire hurricane season prediction in their history With just one week to go before the official start of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, meteorologists at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration are predicting the busiest storm season the agency has ever forecasted—a potentially devastating warning for the East Coast and Gulf of Mexico following a string of devastating storm seasons.
If both forecasts hold true, the 2024 season would surpass the 19 named storms and seven hurricanes observed last year, as well as the 14 named storms recorded in 2022.
Only one Atlantic hurricane made landfall in the U.S. last year.
The hurricane season officially starts on June 1 and lasts through the end of November, though hurricanes can come outside that timeframe.
As of Thursday, however, NOAA’s National Hurricane Center is not forecasting any Atlantic hurricanes or tropical storms over the next 48 hours.
event_breakdown:
- NOAA predicts the most devastating hurricane season in history,
- The New York region is prepping for a collision with a potentially massive hurricane this week,
- A cat 2 hurricane is believed to have cored a weaker and slower-moving system, allowing the currents to carry it into the Gulf Coast region,
- The storm surge warnings are expected to impact several parts of the coastline right now.

title: Ocean Heat And La Nina Combo Likely Mean More Atlantic Hurricanes This Summer
message:
Get ready for what nearly all the experts think will be one of the busiest Atlantic hurricane seasons on record, thanks to unprecedented ocean heat and a brewing La Nina.
An average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.
A La Nina tends to turbocharge Atlantic storm activity while depressing storminess in the Pacific and an El Nino does the opposite.
La Nina usually reduces high-altitude winds that can decapitate hurricanes, and generally during a La Nina there’s more instability or storminess in the atmosphere, which can seed hurricane development.
Instead of a La Nina, there was a strong El Nino, which usually inhibits storminess a bit.
event_breakdown: 1. Atlantic hurricane season predicted to be one of the busiest on record.

title: These Tips Can Help Keep You Safe During A Potentially Severe 2024 Wildfire Season
message:
Many regions of Canada experienced over 40 days where air pollution concentrations exceeded the World Health Organization's air quality guidelines , leading to periods where Canada had some of the worst air quality in the world .
These fires, known as“holdover” fires, along with Canada's warmest winter on record and extreme drought in many regions , fuelled an early start to the 2024 wildfire season .
Simply put, these early season fires and current weather conditions indicate that Canada may be on track for another severe wildfire season.
Strategies to prepare for a summer of wildfire smokeAs Canada faces the potential of another severe wildfire season, it is important to be prepared for prolonged and intense periods of wildfire smoke.
Interactive maps like AirNow and PurpleAir allow you to easily check current air quality conditions using the Air Quality Index .

Wildfire season in Canada

Warmest winter on record

title: National Hurricane Center releases most - active preseason forecast in history
message:
CHARLESTON, S.C. (WCSC/AP) - The National Hurricane Center released what it called the most active pre-season forecast in the agency’s history, calling for a “hyperactive” Atlantic hurricane season.
There’s an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season that starts in June will be above average in storm activity, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced Thursday in its annual outlook.
Administrators at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration say water temperatures are a big contributing factor to the forecast as well as a brewing La Niña.
La Niña usually reduces high-altitude winds that can decapitate hurricanes, and generally during a La Niña there’s more instability or storminess in the atmosphere, which can seed hurricane development.
Peak hurricane season usually is mid-August to mid-October with the official season starting June 1 and ending Nov. 30.
event_breakdown:
Events:
1. A very active Atlantic hurricane season is predicted.
2. La Nina will likely play a role in fueling more frequent hurricanes.
3. Atlantic Ocean is expected to have warmer than average temperatures.

title: Orlando weather : Hot , hot , hot Memorial Day weekend on tap across Central Florida
message:
It's Memorial Day weekend – and we're on track for a near-record heat weekend with very low rain chances through the middle of next week.
In fact, the high pressure system inducing this heat wave stays put stubbornly through next week with mid-to-upper 90s remaining across our region.
This will limit our typical afternoon storm chances to less than 30% in most cases next week.
At worst, a tropical system may try to come together in the Caribbean, focusing all that rain into a concentrated area.
If that happens, our overall rain chances would likely diminish unless said potential system was to track into Florida.

title: UN weather agency anticipates highly active hurricane season | World News

The World Meteorological Organization on Friday said it expected a highly active hurricane season and stressed that early warnings were needed to save lives.
"High ocean heat content and the anticipated development of La Nina event are expected to fuel a very, very, very active hurricane season this year," Clare Nullis, WMO spokesperson, told a briefing in Geneva.
"It only takes one landfalling hurricane to set back years and years of socio-economic development."
The Atlantic hurricane season, which lasts from June to November, has recorded above average activity for eight consecutive years, WMO said.
Between 1970 and 2021, tropical cyclones -- which include hurricanes -- were the leading cause of reported human and economic losses worldwide, according to WMO.

title: NOAA predicts busy Atlantic hurricane season
message:
Forecasters at the National Weather Service are predicting a busy Atlantic hurricane season this year amid near-record warm ocean temperatures and the development of La Nina conditions in the Pacific.
Up to 25 named storms are expected.
The annual forecast, released just a week before the start of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, shows an 85% chance of an above-normal season, a 10% chance of a near-normal season and a 5% chance of a below-normal season.
The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 through November 30, with peak activity between August and October.
An average season, based on data since 1981, produces fourteen named storms, with seven becoming hurricanes and three major hurricanes.

title: Hurricane forecast points to a dangerous 2024 Atlantic season
message:
The 2024 Atlantic hurricane season starts on June 1, and forecasters are predicting an exceptionally active season.
Forecasters and climatologists look for two main clues when assessing the risks from upcoming Atlantic hurricane seasons: a warm tropical Atlantic Ocean and a cool tropical eastern Pacific Ocean.
Warm Atlantic water can fuel hurricanesDuring the summer, the Atlantic Ocean warms up, resulting in generally favorable conditions for hurricanes to form.
This ocean tag team controls hurricane activityThe Atlantic and eastern Pacific ocean temperatures together control Atlantic hurricane activity.
The record 2020 hurricane season had the influence of both La Niña and high Atlantic ocean temperatures, and that's what forecasters expect to see in 2024.

title: SunLive - The need to prepare for megathrust earthquake
message:
Whakatāne needs to prepare for a megathrust earthquake and resulting tsunami similar in size and strength to the 2011 Japan event, local GNS researcher Dr Mawera Karetai says.
She has planned a series of workshops with GNS seismologists for next month as she feels most people in town are “woefully ill-prepared” for an earthquake.
“When we have a magnitude 9 earthquake the roading network will fail completely.
We have to prepare for infrastructure damage, liquefaction, fountaining fresh water from broken pipes and raw sewage,” she says.
The first of these, Earthquake Day, is intended for community leaders from organisations such as councils, schools, police and healthcare agencies.

message:

May is the most active "out-of-season" month for tropical development in the Atlantic.

title: In Brazil , mangrove reforestation proves crucial in fight against climate risks
message:
Brazil’s southern state of Rio Grande do Sul is still reeling from a devastating flood earlier this month that wreaked havoc and took lives, with waters far from subsiding to normal levels.
The reforestation in Rio's bay improved the cleanliness of water that's a breeding ground for marine species.
A lack of mangroves wasn’t the cause of flooding around Rio Grande do Sul's capital, Porto Alegre, that sits beside a lagoon.
The coastal risk map created by Climate Central, a nonprofit science research group, forecasts areas west and north of Porto Alegre will be underwater by 2100.
Environmentalists say the loss of natural vegetation due to agriculture and cattle ranching in Rio Grande do Sul state amplified the flooding.

Mangroves slow sea water's advance into riverbeds during storm surges by soaking it up, and protects the land by stabilizing soil that otherwise could be washed away.

title: Clouds & showers for Memorial Day weekend
message:
ANCHORAGE, Alaska (KTUU) - A circulating area of low pressure will slowly move out of the Bering Sea and head toward the Gulf of Alaska as we move through Friday.
This storm will be the weather driver over the weekend, with another low rotating into the western Aleutian Chain by Sunday.
Scattered showers will be a factor through much of the rest of the weekend over the region.
Flood watches continue for snowmelt flooding on the Yukon River at Fort Yukon, the Porcupine River, and again on the Yukon River downstream of Mountain Village down to the Yukon Delta coast.
Thursday’s hot spot went to Fort Yukon at 62 degrees.
event_breakdown:
1. A circulating area of low pressure moving from Bering Sea to Gulf of Alaska
2. Another low rotating into the western Aleutian Chain
3. Flood watches for snowmelt flooding on Yukon River
4. Flood watch on Porcupine River
5. Flood watch on Yukon River downstream of Mountain Village to Yukon Delta coast

title: NOAA predicts above - normal 2024 Atlantic Hurricane Season : See their prediction
message:
NOAA has released its seasonal hurricane outlook for the Atlantic basin, and due to warm waters and a diminishing El Niño, the agency believes the year could be ferocious.
It's the greatest number of hurricanes predicted by NOAA in its annual May forecast, surpassing the forecast of 14-23 storms in 2010.
2024 ATLANTIC HURRICANE SEASON GUIDE: HERE’S WHAT TO KNOW ABOUT THIS YEAR’S STORMSContinued record warm water temperatures across the Atlantic, with a neutral or even a La Niña climate pattern in place are expected to lead to high counts of cyclones.
But meteorologists stress that no matter whether the hurricane season is predicted to be busy or quiet, being prepared is imperative.
If you get impacted, it will be the worst hurricane season you have been through."

Atlantic hurricane season 2024

title: Warming Climate Intensifies Flash Droughts Worldwide
message:
Sudden, severe dry spells known as flash droughts are rising in intensity around the world, with a notable exception in mountainous Central Asia, where flash drought extent is shrinking, according to new research.
Flash droughts arrive suddenly, within weeks, hitting communities that are often not prepared and causing lasting impact.
Land cover is also important to flash drought vulnerability.
Savanna and grasslands are more susceptible to flash droughts than other ecotypes, particularly in humid and semi-humid climates, the study found.
In Central Asian watersheds, centered on high mountains, including the Himalaya Karakoram, Tianshan and Hindu Kush, flash drought extent shrank over the study period, bucking the worldwide trend.
location: The main location where the flash droughts occur is Central Asia. The flash drought extent in Central Asia
event_breakdown: Flash droughts.

The flooding Thursday also hit areas of Porto Alegre, including the south, which had previously gone unscathed.
Earlier this week, the city of Porto Alegre had asked residents to leave their trash out on the sidewalk to be thrown away.

title: Drought conditions have eased , but Calgarians still asked to  make every drop count
message:
As of Friday morning Environment Canada said 50.9 millimetres of precipitation had fallen so far this month at Calgary International Airport.
That includes 42.1 mm of rain and 8.8 mm of snow and is just short of the average precipitation for May.
In a normal year, the airport weather station records 56.8 of precipitation in May, including 46.1 mm of rain and 11.9 mm of snow.
However, with showers and the possibility of thundershowers in the forecast throughout the weekend there’s a strong chance Calgary will approach or exceed the normal precipitation levels this month.
Environment Canada says in a normal year the Calgary airport weather station records 56.8 of precipitation for the month of May.

title: NJ earthquake shakes Gladstone this morning – NBC10 Philadelphia
message:
Yet another earthquake was recorded in New Jersey overnight, not far from the location where the U.S. Geological Survey reported two other quakes in recent weeks -- and a rare magnitude 4.8 quake in early April.
This time, it was a 2.9 magnitude, USGS says, recorded about 4 miles west-southwest of Gladstone in Somerset County.
The same area saw a 2.9 magnitude earthquake days earlier.
It follows dozens of aftershocks following that relatively "big" 4.8 magnitude earthquake that rattled more than 40 million people on the East Coast shortly before the solar eclipse.
The New Jersey magnitude 4.8 earthquake was felt from hundreds of miles away, with some in the tri-state feeling the Earth move under their feet for the first time ever.

2.9 magnitude earthquake just east of Gladstone (Somerset County), New Jersey

title: Severe storm in Coleman shatters windows and brings community together
message:
Severe storms swept through Coleman yesterday afternoon.
Heavy rainfall caused multiple streets to be blocked off due to flooding, and residents say hail showered Coleman for approximately 30 minutes.
Martin Quinonez says he was at work when the storm struck, but his wife and kids were home.
My wife’s whole family was here to tarp and cardboard everything.”Busted windows and shattered home structures are a common sight in Coleman due to the severe storm that struck around 3 p.m. on Wednesday.
Quinonez says the storm may have caused many people to panic but it also brought out the community’s kindness.

title: 2 . 9 magnitude N . J . earthquake reportedly felt on Staten Island
message:
STATEN ISLAND, N.Y. — An early morning 2.9 magnitude N.J. earthquake was reportedly felt on Staten Island.
The tremor took place around 3.7 miles west-southwest of Gladstone, N.J., around 3:50 a.m. Friday, according to the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS).
While no damage has been reported from the incident, light shaking was felt as far as the North Shore of Staten Island, as noted by the USGS “Did You Feel It” page.
In the wake of the initial 4.8 magnitude earthquake back on April 5, there have been at least 160 aftershocks, with the majority falling below a 2.0 magnitude, as reported by NJ.com.
In the moments following the first quake, officials warned of the potential for aftershocks in the weeks to come.
event_breakdown:
1. A 2.9 magnitude N.J. Earthquake was reportedly felt in the early morning on Staten Island on Friday .
2. No damage has been reported from the quake, but light shaking was felt as far as the North Shore of Staten Island .
3. There have been at least 160 aftershocks after the initial 4.8 magnitude earthquake .
